deltas.text: A switch is a manually controlled device that opens or closes a circuit.
This site implements four switches: SPST, DPST, SPDT, and DPDT (in reading order). S stands for single, D for double; P for pole, T for throw.
The number of poles refers to the number of input poles.
The number of throws refers to the number of possible output poles per input pole.
The SPST (Single-Pole Single-Throw) is your standard switch; either open or closed.
The SPDT (Single-Pole Double-Throw) is a two-way switch, where one of the two output poles is always connected to the input pole.
The DPST (Double-Pole Single-Throw) mechanically links two SPST switches such that they are both open or both closed.
The DPDT (Double-Pole Double-Throw) mechanically links two SPDT switches similarly to the DPST. Look at that chonker.
Here are all of the switches again, for reference. (In order: SPST, DPST, SPDT, DPDT.)
You can modify the switch "values" to let it turn on/off. 1 is 'on', 0 is 'off'.
